Well, all one can say, by looking at the dynamics unfolding in the rest of the world and here at home is: I wish the democratization also happened here. But it won't. The difference is that in other countries Big Money cannot buy the whole political process the way it happens here. Citizen United and campaign contributions ( and the obscene cost of political campaigns, from President to local judges) are untouched by the larger processes at work in the rest of the world. As a consequence we will end up with a much less truly democratic system at the same time that it democracy spreads all over the globe. And since democracy is the secret weapon of the ideals of equality and social justice, we will have less and less of both.

I wonder what Mr. Friedman means by a "leader"? I suspect he means an upholder of vested interests and the kind of bourgeois ideals of democracy, precisely the thing that is failing. Typically what you find as "leaders" are spokespersons like Obama. A few lucky countries at least have a spokesperson with grounding in hard disciplines like Merkel. However an original thinker, suitable for the opportunity and challenges is unlikely to be found, and if found is almost certain to be rejected by the pundit class as lacking in spokesperson credibility.

It must be from the intellectual class that such (real) leadership eventually comes though. How much turmoil this century will see before the new class relations settles is anybody's guess at this point.

Friedman is right, of course. I run a company with several centers that serve the public. Prior to 2010, if we so chose, we could sweep customer complaints and employee grievances under the rug. WIth the advent of social media and review sites, this is no longer possible. If an employee treats a consumer wrong, or even if a consumer takes offense at a seemingly trivial mistake, those grievances are going to be posted online, usually anonymously, in a very public and permanent forum.

What consumers, however, do not understand, is that this new empowerment does come with responsiblity. Employees also have families and colleagues; blistering online attacks can be very painful and damaging to careers and businesses.

Whereas businesses have to conduct themselves to certain standards - there are penalties for libel for example - social media sites, and review sites can post libelous reviews with impunity. And it is not as if these review sites have the most scrupulous standards, either. Just google "yelp extortion" to read just a fraction of the story.

There needs to be a reckoning on both sides.

I can only assume that Steve Lohr is aware that much of what he mentions in the article has been online for quite some time. I imagine the marriage between computer hardware, microwave communications and software will  enable us to do almost everything before long and that we are heading for science fiction hell faster than anyone has a clue about.  Most conspicuously in the military, weapons target acquisition systems, click your dead style. Weaponised intelligence gathering drones can do an awful lot of handy things around the globe while a guy in Nevada manipulates a joy stick. Then we have smart meters installed by our electrical utilities. Lojack enables the police to find your stolen car via GPS tech. And there are no doubt thousands of different varieties of microswitches connected to  millions of pieces of hardware via computers doing everything you can imagine and if you own a late model high end auto you are utilizing a lot of this stuff every time you drive, much of it coupled to the internet. Can you say On-star? Or whatever its called. Think of all the phone apps that activate or could activate pretty much anything from home lighting, to heating or a nuclear attack.

The Internet: Loves me, loves me not... Maybe I'm just a number or a digital ID?

"All good" (maybe) that so much "smart technology" can efficiently oversee so many daily routines and decisions (about grid-sharing, for example).

But I still remember the big issue and efforts around separating out signal from noise, in the area of SPAM and malicious denial-of-service attacks, etc. How did the fight against spam end, please remind me! (Could it be that "spam is good" won out?)
How is the "freedom of the Internet" translated into both hugely positive services and events, versus a gift-wrapped present for computer-hacking spies and criminals?

If we rely completely on computers, Hal (from 2001: A Space Odyssey) will always have the last laugh until/unless managers and programmers prevail to master the technology. Sometimes it appears as if the lure of the Internet and mobile devices is the ball our society keeps its collective eyes on - increasingly celebrating all the joys of "being connected" but less focused on how user experience can be enhanced (e.g., better/cheaper broadband access in the U.S., privacy, eliminating spam, )

Agreed, there are many levels to "the story", and tools are just that, for good and bad - technology generally being defined as that which *improves* daily human life.

I am a 1L at a (public) law school. I can attest that there are many law students who want to do the kind of law that is needed, whether it’s prosecution, defense, or legal aid—but we do need to put a roof over our heads after graduation. However, the focus on the ABA does not, need to be more lenient accreditation.

Having to hire a “brain surgeon” when what you need is a “plumber” is an example of the wrongs of the legal system, to paraphrase Professor Morris. But so is having to hire a plumber when what you need is a brain surgeon, especially if your adversary has a team of brain surgeons at the ready. Loosening the ABA regulations could also mean that poorer people in court are left with lawyers with less preparation than their adversaries. In addition, hiring—at legal aid agencies included—is still based on law school prestige. Expansion of ABA certifications might therefore not have the large effect the article hints.

The focus on ABA should instead be on (1) increasing funding from the government or other sources to legal services corporations—which are sorely in decline, as the Times pointed out back in August; and (2) increasing Loan Repayment Assistance Programs, so that the law students who do take these jobs can do so realistically – not with frills, but with roofs. Without these changes, law students will continue to look for only for the kind of work that is realistic to repay bills, not just the kind of law that is needed. The cycle will continue.
